title: Between 20 September 2019 and 15 October 2019, how many candidates for the Democratic nomination for president of the United States will cease to be candidates?
preds: There is more to gain from staying in until after the next Democratic debate, compare with dropping out the day before. I should have adjusted my forecast to this new forecast a few days ago.
Will Pre-Debate STRESS put Bernie on a Gurney?
No time left, but possible one or two candidates bail over the long weekend.
Well I was way off on this question, I figured we'd have 2-3 like in past cycles between debates. I guess everyone is hoping to make it in November.

Sometimes I take the number of days that a question will be open and ask myself how many % points per day it would take to get from 100 to 0% during that time frame:  for this question it is 4% per day.  Absent any hints or rumors of anyone pulling out in the next week, I'm headed towards 0% for none.

Upping my forecast for zero dropout. Recent health issues with Sanders and drops in polls and funding raising for Biden (possibly related the his son's business dealings) provide more hope to the lesser candidates for staying in.  This is especially true for Delaney who can hope to siphon voters from Biden. (Delaney was identified as a potential dropout in my previous forecast as he reduced his travel to Iowa and NH by half between Aug and September).
Thanks to @Anneinak for this idea.
In this window they are more stringent
8 days left, if candidates haven't dropped due to Q3 fundraising problems, unlikely to drop in next 8 days.  https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/912530

Accidentally changed my forecast. Resubmitting... In terms of Iowa on Feb 3, 2020, the base rate for drop-outs is 32% for fields with over 10 candidates, an occurrence that has happened 6 times across both parties. The Democrats most recent field with over 10 candidates was '88, with Biden and Schroeder dropping out before the primaries, and after Iowa, there were still 11 candidates in the race. Due to the proportional delegate allocation system in the Democratic Party, there is little incentive to drop-out, as opposed to within the Republican Party, where the winner-takes-all system penalizes losers. Forecasting around even tighter windows than between now and Iowa is extremely sensitive to individual campaign situations. One would assume Wayne Messam would have dropped out a long time ago -he is the most likely candidate to drop-out-, but he hasn't. You can split the field into tier 1 candidates, who have over 3% of support in polls -Biden, Buttigieg, Harris, Sanders & Warren-, and tier 2 candidates, who are the rest of the candidates who qualified for the debates, but have less than 3% traction, and assume that none of them will drop-out, including Sanders, whatever his health situation. Tier 3 candidates are the 0-1%ers. Paradoxically, I think, apart from Messam, they have little reason to drop-out, even if they are forced to scale back their activities, because their continued candidacy keeps their brand growing, cf. Williamson, and because they can appeal directly to voters and build support outside traditional structures, cf WIlliamson & Yang. Bullock can use this cycle as a training exercise for the future. Ryan can run two races at once but that may force his hand at some point. Delaney and Ryan may rethink their candidacy but again, they have nothing to lose from staying in the race. Apart from Messam who generates bad or no press, there is no obvious candidate, and Messam's campaign may simply be too inept to formally withdraw.

Why would they make a decision to withdraw in the next 9 days?  Candidates have already had time to make a decision based on Q3 fundraising totals and who made the next DNC debate.   Sanders is not in better health now than he was because of damage to his heart muscle from the heart attack he had and I think that will impact his campaign: his stamina,  his polling and his fund-raising. I'm reading about how Biden is "stumbling"-- hasn't been able to come  up with a coherent response to DJT's attacks on his son--and that he was not the fund-raising leader last quarter.   Could it be that we are seeing the beginning of the end of the Sanders' & Biden campaigns?   If the top candidates look like they may be withdrawing, lower rung candidates may find renewed hope and stick it out longer.  So, I think that the weakening of Sanders & Biden will reduce the number of candidates who withdraw.
A suspension would really throw a monkey wrench into the works now, but another withdrawal would start some Dominoes...

Keyes, once said when the facts change, I change my mind.  What do you do?  Mmm..   Ready, shoot, aim.     
Democrat efforts to impeach trump seems to have shot their candidate.    Lovely.     Course it would help if the democrats weren't sanctimonious crooks in the first place.   I digress.   Expect a campaign shuffle.    Looks like warren's the Dem choice now. So - the interesting thing is... will Warren start running to the center.  Can she?    This is a tad premature, but thats where the power vaccuum is.  Half the democrats are far left - but that vote is split by.. gabbard, harris, bernie, beto, klobuchar, warren, buttigeg...  the moderates with the exception of Joe are all dwarfs, with no significant presence.

https://www.denverpost.com/2019/10/02/michael-bennet-democratic-primary-presidential-debate/ Bennett says he's in until after the early primaries.  He raised only $2.1m in the last quarter and spent more than that, but he has $1.8m in cash and says he's running a lean campaign focused on Iowa and NH.  According to the latest Iowa poll he was polling below 1% there but he has hit 2% in one national poll recently.   He is running as a moderate.

My last forecast on candidate dropouts did not fare well.  Too much significance was given to the loss of exposure from being excluded from the debate.  This time I will try to guess the intentions of the candidates from their travel schedules to the early primary states, especially Iowa and New Hampshire.  Travel schedules can be found in Ballotpedia.org [1]. Instead of looking at the total number of times travelled to the early states, I focused on the months of August and September.  These two months span the time that a large number of candidates lost their participation in the September debate.  The September travel relative to the August provides an indication of whether the candidates still stay to the primaries even with the loss of news coverage from the debates. The potential dropouts are limited to the 7 candidates that did not qualify for the October debates.  (I don’t see any the October qualified candidates dropping out at this time).  They are Bennett, Bullock, Delaney, Messam, Ryan, Sestak and Williamson. ¬¬ Messam is not a serious candidate.  He has never qualified for any of the debates.  He has travelled to Iowa and NH a total of 3 times, and none in August and September.  He is not getting much publicity either.  I don’t understand his intention.  He is a wildcard in term of dropping out.  He might drop out tomorrow or he might stay there for a long time. Delaney travelled a lot to Iowa and NH earlier, but his travel to Iowa dropped from 10 (August) to 2 (September), and from 5 to 3 in NH.  These are significant reduction of travel, indicating a high potential for dropout, especially considering his frequent travels earlier. Ryan’s travel to Iowa dropped by half from 4 to 2 (August to September), but he more than double in his travel to NH (2 to 5).  He is in for the longer haul. The situation is similar for Sestak; reduced from 20 to 12 in Iowa, but increased from 0 to 6 in NH. Bennett, Bullock and Williamson did not change their travel schedule from August to September, indicating that they intend to stay till at least the Iowa and NH primaries.  Williamson even increased her travel to Nevada (from 2 to 4) while the other 6 candidates did not travel there at all. In summary, there is one potential dropout (Delaney) and one wildcard (Messam).  The rest are staying at least beyond the October debate.
[1]  https://ballotpedia.org/Presidential_candidate_campaign_travel,_2020

In terms of Iowa on Feb 3, 2020, the base rate for drop-outs is 32% for fields with over 10 candidates, an occurrence that has happened 6 times across both parties. The Democrats most recent field with over 10 candidates was '88, with Biden and Schroeder dropping out before the primaries, and after Iowa, there were still 11 candidates in the race. Due to the proportional delegate allocation system in the Democratic Party, there is little incentive to drop-out, as opposed to within the Republican Party, where the winner-takes-all system penalizes losers. Forecasting around even tighter windows than between now and Iowa is extremely sensitive to individual campaign situations. One would assume Wayne Messam would have dropped out a long time ago -he is the most likely candidate to drop-out-, but he hasn't. You can split the field into tier 1 candidates, who have over 3% of support in polls -Biden, Buttigieg, Harris, Sanders & Warren-, and tier 2 candidates, who are the rest of the candidates who qualified for the debates, but have less than 3% traction, and assume that none of them will drop-out, including Sanders, whatever his health situation. Tier 3 candidates are the 0-1%ers. Paradoxically, I think, apart from Messam, they have little reason to drop-out, even if they are forced to scale back their activities, because their continued candidacy keeps their brand growing, cf. Williamson, and because they can appeal directly to voters and build support outside traditional structures, cf WIlliamson & Yang. Bullock can use this cycle as a training exercise for the future. Ryan can run two races at once but that may force his hand at some point. Delaney and Ryan may rethink their candidacy but again, they have nothing to lose from staying in the race. Apart from Messam who generates bad or no press, there is no obvious candidate, and Messam's campaign may simply be too inept to formally withdraw.

(12) Invited to the debate are: Joe Biden, Cory Booker, Pete Buttigieg, Julián Castro, Tulsi Gabbard, Kamala Harris, Amy Klobuchar, Beto O’Rourke, Bernie Sanders, Tom Steyer, Elizabeth Warren and Andrew Yang. https://www.politico.com/news/2019/10/02/who-qualified-for-october-democratic-debate-019981  (7) Not invited are Michael Bennet ($2.1M for Q3), Steve Bullock, ($Not reporting and plans to apply for public financing),  John Delaney (team is falling apart), Wayne Messam (polling 0%), Tim Ryan (.3%), Joe Sestak (.2%),  Marianne Williamson (.6%) All 7 of these will drop out. How many in 13 days? Bennett (no), Bullock (no), Delaney (yes), Messam (yes), Ryan (maybe), Sestak (no), Williamson (yes - due to no more debate time). Sanders (maybe), but will want to participate in the debate.  I am adjusting for overconfidence + pressure from the DNC to cull the field.  By my tally, 3 yes and 2 maybe

Sanders has cancelled all campaign events.    There is at least a chance he's thinking about dropping out. 

Polls recently have started turning against him; uniquely his status as a front runner makes him susceptible.  Once the electorate decides against  you, they will rarely reconsider.  Sanders has the perfect out - he can claim health issues.   But at 102, or whatever age he is, I think he's starting to see the writing on the wall.  https://www.thestate.com/news/politics-government/election/article235663427.html This is especially funny, considering democrats have long said its all about the money...
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-10-01/buttigieg-sanders-rake-in-cash-while-struggling-in-surveys https://www.nytimes.com/2019/10/01/us/politics/democrats-q3-fundraising-numbers.html

Bernie Sanders’ hospitalization lowers the distribution. On the one hand it means that Bernie might drop out but as long as he comes back healthy the official drop out of the race for him would likely not come for a while. On the other hand, lower tier candidates will see this as an opportunity to gain in the polling at Sanders’ expense. So I’m increasing first bucket from 39%.
Bernie just had surgery. Two Stints. He may not know it yet - but hes out. That and The Biden Investigation clears the way for Warren who will not collect supporters from waning candidates.

Yesterday there was a rumor that Booker was going to make an announcement on Tuesday, and the assumption was that it was about suspending his campaign, but it seems that the announcement was that he had achieved the discrete donor threshold for the November debate. . . . he still has to meet the polling threshold, though. . . . as does O'Rourke (and others?) EDIT:  Castro is under pressure to withdraw from the presidential race and run for Senate. @Emil

No-one on who has made threshold for the 15 October debate is going to drop out before that.  So starting here: https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/tulsi-gabbard-is-the-12th-candidate-to-make-octobers-democratic-debate/. And trying to confirm who won't be on stage for the debate.
Williamson: no. https://www.texastribune.org/2019/09/12/marianne-williamson-texas-base-support-2020-democrat-debate/
Bennet: no. https://www.denverpost.com/2019/09/12/michael-bennet-2020-lakewood-trump/
Bullock: no. https://www.mtpr.org/post/bullock-fails-qualify-third-democratic-debate
Delaney: no.  https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/november-debate-thresholds-will-imperil-several-more-democratic-presidential-campaigns/2019/09/23/d555c37e-de2d-11e9-b199-f638bf2c340f_story.html
Ryan: no. https://www.washingtonexaminer.com/opinion/op-eds/tim-ryan-is-at-home-in-the-presidential-race
Sestak: https://www.phillyvoice.com/joe-sestak-campaign-running-for-president-democratic-primary-chestnut-hill-college/
Messam: no. https://www.latimes.com/politics/story/2019-09-11/candidates-who-did-not-make-the-democratic-debate-marianne-williamson-tulsi-gabbard How many of those will stick it out anyway?  Not many.  But they may not announce prior to the debate.  In fact, I'm now thinking most will wait until after.
Rumors Booker will have an announcement on Tuesday.

End of the quarter financing will be a critical issue for several candidates.   At least two will drop out due to low quarterly fundraising. I think at least one more will drop out for reasons other than fundraising problems, such as losing momentum/dropping moral of their staff team. Staff will start to jump at the first hint of not being paid in the future, because they have to support themselves and families.  https://www.washingtonexaminer.com/news/five-things-to-watch-in-third-quarter-democratic-presidential-fundraising

https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/beto-orourke-jokes-kitten-attract-donors/story?id=65927884 "According to the DNC, candidates must cross one of the two polling requirements and receive money from at least 165,000 individual donors, an increase from 130,000 for the fall debates, to qualify. For polling requirements, Democratic hopefuls must earn at least 3% in four or more national or early-state -- Iowa, New Hampshire, South Carolina, Nevada -- polls, a modest bump from the last round of debates, or get at least 5% in two early-state polls. To cross the first polling threshold, each of the qualifying polls must have a different sponsor -- or be in a different geographical area if it's the same sponsor. But with far less polling coming from the early states, for a candidate to qualify via the second avenue, the DNC is allowing for two early-state polls to be in the same geographical areas and from the same sponsors.
. . . 
At least two candidates and their teams, former HUD Secretary Julián Castro and Sen. Cory Booker, have made dramatic appeals for donations by sounding the alarm of possibly ending their bids.
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  The window for this question is 3 weeks, one of which is passed.

It is also worth pointing out that candidates may see an opportunity to gain some polling percentages should Biden go down in wake of the Ukraine investigations, particularly low-polling candidates that are centrists like Bullock, which lowers their odds of dropping out now.

Gabbard has qualified for the 4th debate, reducing her chances of dropping out. Others have kept up campaigning according to Ballotpedia. Though many may drop out soon (Messam, Sestak, Ryan, Bennet) the timeframe for this question is very short, which is why I have reduced their chances significantly (people with highest chance are assumed at 25%) . Latest odds of dropping out by 15 October: 0.01, #Gabbard
0.20, #Bennet
0.05, #Bullock
0.25, # Ryan
0.04, # Williamson
0.05, #Delaney
0.25, #Sestak
0.25, #Messam
@Achohen makes a lot of sense: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/908861 Reaffirming my forecast. I have a slightly different take on the weights, but agree general with the approach.

Polling data shows a clear disinterest, on an almost global scale for multiple candidates. This, coupled with an oversaturation of the candidacy pool, and a lack of media coverage will drive several parties out of the race in my opinion.

Based on prior questions, we lose a couple between each debate. However, each prior question has only looked at the participants of each debate, not the total universe of candidates. I'm not sure that matters since most of the extra people really should have dropped out (Messam), or really should have known better in the first place (Sestak). so I don't think they are going anywhere. The top five (Biden, Buttigieg, Harris, Sanders, and Warren) aren't going anywhere, nor is anyone else who has already made the cut for the October debate (Booker, Castro, Gabbard, Klobuchar, O'Rourke, Steyer, and Yang) since what politician ever turned down free national airtime. That leaves five candidates that I think could drop out, individual notes below. Michael Bennet-A definite dropout possibility. I don't think he is facing any pressure in Colorado since he isn't up for reelection in 2020 but it is also pretty clear that he hasn't caught on and probably won't at this point. Steve Bullock-He's facing a lot of pressure to switch to running for senate, seems like a dropout possibility John Delaney-This guy was one of the richest members of the house and can bankroll his campaign until either an asteroid hits the earth or people stop laughing at his campaign. I'm serious, he's that rich. Tim Ryan-Is he still running? Also seems like a dropout possibility since he's got a political future running for things in Ohio Marianne Williamson-I don't think she has any reason to drop out before June, not least because I don't think you are allowed to give a concession speech astride a purple rainbow burping Two-nicorn (https://simpsons.fandom.com/wiki/Two-nicorn) Point is I think two candidates have a good chance of dropping out (Bennet & Bullock) but there are enough left that someone else may dropout too.

I don't think that gabbard is going to drop. New Hampshire is a cheap state to do media purchase. And considering the tiny sizes of the polls there... 5oo people, one could theoretically qualify with 25 people. Additionally.... It's kind of like a game of chicken.  As people drop, their voters redistribute.  So one or more drops encourage the remainder to stay. There is interesting movement.  Warren is picking up steam, Sanders is fading in n.h.
It has the feel that Democrats are starting to congeal.

I realized that assuming an 80% chance of a Messam drop out is probably too high. I still think he is very likely to drop out soon, but 80% in the short time span of the next 3 weeks is perhaps too high.  Reallocating 9% from the 3rd to the 1st bucket.

None) Most candidates are dropping out around fundraising and debate deadlines. However, the next debate deadline is October 1st and it has the same criteria as the last debate. So many candidates who didn't think that they would make the last debate and would have used that as a reason to drop out, are still in the race. As a result, I think that this is the 2nd most likely option after "one or two." I think it is more likely that no one drops out than 3-4 candidates drop out since looking at the qualification standards the only person who is on the line is Tulsi Gabbard. 2) One or two, I specifically think that one candidate will drop out. If I had to guess it would be booker or Gabbard. The other candidates don't really have a reason to drop out, although something could happen to Messam or Tim Ryan to decide to call it quit (it's hard to understand their logic for running anyway). I put this above 50% because there are enough candidates that I find it likely someone will drop out. 3) See the logic on part 1. The campaigns that I think are close to dropping out are Booker and Gabbard and I doubt both of them will drop out. That being said, it is close simply because their are so many unknowns as it relates to the small campaigns. 4) I don't think we will see this kind of quelling until the 4th debate deadline or until Iowa.

DNC sets November Criteria: 
https://www.politico.com/story/2019/09/23/dnc-debate-1508516 Seems like they addressed Gabbard's concerns. 
News monkey penalized.

Adjusting distribution down slightly for passage of time. The new debate requirements are in line with my expectations of a small tightening.  https://www.nytimes.com/2019/09/23/us/politics/democratic-debate-criteria.html

Based on previous trend of slowness in dropouts, not many are expected to drop this early. There are still about 4 months to Iowa when major action is expected. At this point two factors will dominate the dropout. First and more important is money and second is candidate's diminishing value among voters. 
For example, do John Delaney really thinks that he can become US president?...not a remote chance right? Still he is there are will go away at some point.
My rough calculation shows about 3.66 to drop out and may be more if money runs out with no future in sight.
Copying Emil for now until I can do more research
I think some people, such as Marianne Williamson, will not drop out but will just fade away.

10 met the "polling and fundraising requirements set out by the Democratic National Committee" to qualify for the Sept 12 debate (https://www.ft.com/content/61668a98-2596-11e9-8ce6-5db4543da632) 2/6 withdrew in 2015 on or just after Oct 20
0/10 withdrew in 2007 before that date
Mostly agree with the excellent analysis by @Emil , but I'm assuming Booker also has a non-negligible chance of dropping out.

Refining my original analysis [1] after more research. The new probabilities for individual candidates are:
0.1, #Gabbard (unchanged)
0.25, #Bennet (down from 33% - a relatively recent article mentions him committing to stay despite debate qualification issues [7], he also got recent endorsement and media attention [8])
0.07, #Bullock (down from 15% - had a positive coverage in the Atlantic two days ago [2], seen as genuinely committed to stay [4], actively campaigning, just began a 3-day tour in IA [5], not running for the Senate [4])
0.33, # Ryan (unchanged)
0.05, #Williamson (unchanged)
0.07, #Delaney (down from 10% - well (self-) funded, , is actively campaigning in IA and NH [3])
0.45, #Sestak  (down from 50% - doing a lot of traveling in IA [3 - see table at the end] 
0.8, #Messam (up from 50%, not doing much traveling [6], not much media coverage) New results: Chance of 0: 0.0432
Chance of 1-2: 0.608
Chance of 3-4: 0.3322
Chance of 5+: 0.0166 Further [4] raises a good argument that the way candidate will go out is by gradually losing the attention of the media and voters and less so because there is pressure for them to bow out (like there was on Hickenlooper).  To watch:
- This article [4] argues Messam and Sestak have the highest chances. I agree about Messam but will have to watch Sestak closely. 
- a big uncertainty is how individual campaigns are doing financially. The latest data is as of end of June from Ballotpedia. Campaign finances are a major factor that might lead a number of campaigns to lose oxygen and simply be forced to close down even if the candidate is committed to staying in. [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/907168
[2] https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2019/09/steve-bullock-wont-drop-out/598396/
[3] https://ballotpedia.org/John_Delaney_presidential_campaign,_2020
[4] "Bullock genuinely seems to be in it for the long haul." http://nymag.com/intelligencer/2019/09/when-will-the-2020-democrats-with-no-chance-drop-out.html
[5] https://ballotpedia.org/Steve_Bullock_presidential_campaign,_2020
[6] https://ballotpedia.org/Wayne_Messam_presidential_campaign,_2020
[7] https://denver.cbslocal.com/2019/08/29/michael-bennet-presidential-race-not-qualifying-debate/

Ok... So the undercard is  Bennet, Delaney, Gabbard, Williamson, Ryan, Bullock, Messam, and Sestak  Bennet  and Delaney have a gig where they appear together.   Delaney probably defraying most of the costs.   The bobsey twins are in.  Sestak.. eccentric.  Establishment hates him.  No idea how he's funding his campaign.  
On the other side:  he's probably burnishing his credentials, showing that he makes no gaffes.  Wants to be included on a ticket as a military experience draw, or in a cabinet.   He's in it to lose it; I expect he will stick around so long as the money lasts, or until he embarasses himself.  Gabbard has the most riding on making the next debate, since she's raised the issue.   BTW, the machine is putting its finger on the scale again, in subtle ways, this time by not releasing the requirements for the November debate.  Could it be they will be looking at the candidates and seeing who they want out?  Anyway, most likely to have a meltdown.  Zero chance early, good chance late. 

Messam.   IS actually campaigning.    No budget.  I don't see a reason to think he will drop out in the month. Williamson.... went on Fox.  Is there room for a civil leftie, one who tries kindness.
Going on Fox was smart politics.   She has that field almost to her self.  TLDR:   Williamson and Gabbard have the biggest stakes riding on the debates.   Crucial dates:  When requirements for Nov released, and when qualifying for Oct is determined.  The DNC wants to winnow the field.   They will set the requirments for November to do that....

I think @Emil's analysis is good: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/907168 Plus Anneinak's additions: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/907186 My addition: Fringe candidates will hang on even if they don't qualify for the next debate. They know they can't win and have other reasons for hanging on other than a realistic possibility to win. So they won't drop out early.  I think the probability of "none" is close to zero. At least one will drop by then. Indeed, at least one will drop by October 15. So, putting this at 1%, although probably should be 0. Five or more by October 15? No.

Gosh, there's not much that I can add to @Emil's analysis here:  https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/907168 Except, he makes the assumption that none of the 11 who have qualified for the next debate will drop out.  I'm going to add a few % to "One or two" in case one of the qualifiers gets themself into such deep trouble that they have to pull out.

~~~
Outside View
~~~ As I previously calculated, the base rate is that 32% of candidates cease to be candidates by the February caucuses, with a standard deviation of 11 percentage points. [1] Roughly speaking this means that ~14 candidates would still be around in February, and no fewer than 10 candidates will be around in February (2 standard deviations away from the mean). So in the worst case scenario, 10 are to drop out by February. How many will drop out in the next month? If we divide the months equally it means 1-2 candidates to drop out in the next month. ~~~
Inside View
~~~ The DNC is trying to winnow the field more aggressively than has been done in previous primaries. 11 candidates have qualified for the fourth debate in October [2].  Let's assume all of these candidates' chances of dropping out now are 0.  Below are those who are left along with my initial assessment of the likelihood. Gabbard - close to qualifying, let's say 10%
Bennet - has vowed to stay in past the 3rd debate [4], let's say 33%
Bullock - has vowed to stay in [3], let's say 15%
Ryan - has vowed to stay [5] , let's say 33%
Williamson - not much to lose from staying, let's say 5%
Delaney - has vowed to stay repeatedly, let's say 10%
Sestak - 50%
Messam - 50% Result: 
	Probability
0	0.0724
1	0.2610
2	0.3342
3	0.2254
4	0.0880
5	0.0172
6	0.0016
7	0.0002 Also worth noting - DNC is set to narrow the criteria for the November debate [6]. Arguably, fringe candidates have stuck around because even if they didn't qualify for the 3rd debate they had a shot at the 4th because the criteria remained unchanged. However, the more the DNC tightens the rules, we should expect more drop outs. ~~~
Conclusion
~~~ The Outside and Inside Views are more or less in agreement.  To watch:
- candidates who won't qualify for the 4th debate but have vowed to stay on - watch whether they remain committed
- fringe candidates like Sestak and Messam. I don't know much about them and my forecast is sensitive to more information about them.
- just how strict will the criteria for the Nov. debate be [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/874330
[2] https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/at-least-11-candidates-will-make-the-fourth-democratic-debate/
[3] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/900465
[4] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/900705
[5] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/901273©
[6] https://www.politico.com/story/2019/09/20/democratic-debates-2020-1505058

To qualify for the 4th Democratic debate, candidates have to meet the same criteria that they needed for the 3rd debate but with a longer qualifying period. (Candidates must attract both 2 percent support in four qualifying national or early-state polls released between June 28 and Oct. 1, and collect contributions from 130,000 unique donors (including at least 400 individual donors in at least 20 states). - https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/at-least-11-candidates-will-make-the-fourth-democratic-debate/)  This means that there is an incentive for those who are towards the lower end of the polls to stay in until at least the end of the qualifying period (Oct 1st), but with only 10 days to go and three polls needed for 7 of the candidates who are on 0 it is unlucky they will make the debate.  2 more candidates (Williamson, Gabbard) can conceivably make the debates on Oct 15th, if they get 1 or two more polls showing they are in the 2% range.  There are therefore 7 candidates who are most likely to drop out - the bottom 7 who won't reach the debates. We have lost the 7 of the 26 candidates since the opening of the race.  In the relatively comparable republican nomination for 2016 (where there were double digit figures) by this time we had lost 2 of the 17 candidates.  Given that de Blasio dropped out today, I think that we will see 3-4 of the lowest polling candidates drop out as some can still run for senate/house races and will need to get funding organised, but some of the lowest polling candidates will stay in to boost their national profile/sell books.
